statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Georgia 97, Southern University 37
article.story: ATHENS, Ga. (AP) -- Georgia was so sharp on both ends of the floor in its 97-37 victory over Southern in its season-opener Friday night that coach Dennis Felton, normally difficult to please, was left with no complaints. What was there to complain about. Georgia shot 61.8 percent from the field, recorded 21 steals and outrebounded Southern 44-29. The Bulldogs also scored 51 points off turnovers. "I don't think we could have played much better," Felton said. Minutes later, however, Felton acknowledged his best full team was not in uniform. Watching from the bench was forward Takais Brown, a junior college transfer who is serving an indefinite academic suspension imposed by Felton. "I think we are a great team right now," said Georgia sophomore Rashaad Singleton. "With Takais we're a special team. Takais, he's just a man's man. I can't wait. He's something special." Brown (6-8, 250) was projected as a starting power forward before the suspension. "It sure would be big for us to have him," Felton said, adding Brown is eligible to play now. "I'm just trying to do the wisest thing, when it comes to him and when it comes to our team," Felton said, adding Brown's return is "really going to be up to Takais." "He's just got to come to grips with he's here to be a student first." Georgia also was without guard Channing Toney Friday night due to a one-game suspension for a violation of the team's academic policy last summer. Felton said Toney, a returning starter, would be back for Georgia's next home game, against Western Kentucky on Tuesday night. The Bulldogs showed impressive depth even without Brown and Toney, who watched the game in street clothes on the Georgia bench. Billy Humphrey, who didn't start, scored a career-high 23 points, making 7 of 8 3-point attempts. "My teammates were feeding me," Humphrey said. "I had the easy part. All I had to do was shoot the ball." Humphrey was 2-for-2 on free throws and did not attempt a shot inside the 3-point line. "For the last two weeks or so he has just been on fire in practice," Felton said of Humphrey. Mike Mercer added 21 points for the Bulldogs. Singleton, a 7-foot sophomore center, also set a career high with 14 points. Steve Newman and freshman center Albert Jackson each added 10 points with a game-high eight rebounds. "I think our fans are just starting to realize why I've been so excited about Albert," Felton said. "He has the capacity to make a huge impact on our team this year." Georgia opened the game with three steals -- each leading to a basket -- in the first minute. A three-point play by Singleton capped a 16-0 run for a 27-5 lead. Southern's final points of the half came on their first 2-point field goal of the game, leaving Georgia with a 50-14 lead. Georgia's 21 steals were only four off the team record of 25 against Yale in 1984. "We really, really want to be disruptive with our defense," Felton said. The 60-point win was Georgia's largest margin of victory in a home game since a 122-62 win over Wittier in 1979. Overall, it was Georgia's largest margin of victory since a 117-50 win at Mercer in 1990. Chris Davis led Southern with 12 points. "Georgia obviously has good size and good guard play and good perimeter shooting, and if they continue to rebound like they did tonight they could do very well," said Southern coach Rob Spivery. Guards Deforrest Riley-Smith, who had 10 points, and Steffon Wiley are the only returning starters for Southern. The Jaguars won the Southwestern Athletic Conference last season and lost to Duke in the first round of the NCAA tournament to finish 19-13. Spivery was upset his team was overmatched from the start. "I was very disappointed in our competitiveness," Spivery said. "We just did not challenge them enough or compete with them."
